messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Vietnam War Movies, Books?
messages.msgSnippet: ... Ours does.  I just ordered the first one.  Who knows?  Maybe he ll be interested.  I finally found out which one he s watching.  It s called Tour of Duty.
messages.messageBody:
>Our library branch bought the whole PBS series
>"Vietnam" It is surprisingly good. DH even watched all
>of it. He refuses to view any movies that
>fictionalize or dramatize that war. Perhaps a library
>somewhere has this series?

Ours does. I just ordered the first one. Who knows? Maybe he'll be
interested. I finally found out which one he's watching. It's called Tour
of Duty. It's on every weekday.


>Will Lars read for info? If so I can put together a
>list of book suggestions.

He won't, but I read to him when he wants. Historical fiction about the
war would probably catch his interest, such as it is at this point. (I
don't want to go whole hog unless he does.)


>Food (cook books, resteraunts), dance (religious and
>secular), biology (flora and fauna...snakes etc) might
>extend his interest. He might enjoy seeing a Veterans
>Honoring Dance at a pow-wow.

I'll save this list in case it *does* become more of an interest.


>Is there a veterans organization that meets somewhere?
>If so, there are probably local vets who would allow
>him to sit in on meetings, or perhaps they have
>literature or someone has photographs (and personal
>comments...take with a grain of salt) to share.
>Actually take all of it with salt. History is created
>in the telling.

Probably not a whole lot of Vietnam vets here in Canada. <g> I do have a
good friend who was a deserter, but he doesn't like to talk about it.


>MASH was Korea. Similar. But way different, too.

Yup.
Tia


No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
Eleanor Roosevelt
*********************************************
Tia Leschke
leschke@...
On Vancouver Island

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Vietnam War Movies, Books?
messages.msgSnippet: ... If you can find a Video Hound movie guide they have a section at the back that lists movies by subject. It might even break them down by particular war.
messages.messageBody:
on 5/1/02 9:29 PM, Tia Leschke at leschke@... wrote:

> I'm
> wondering if anyone can suggest movies or books that I could offer him that
> might extend this interest.

If you can find a Video Hound movie guide they have a section at the back
that lists movies by subject. It might even break them down by particular
war.

Joyce

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Vietnam War Movies, Books?
messages.msgSnippet: Our library branch bought the whole PBS series Vietnam It is surprisingly good. DH even watched all of it.  He refuses to view any movies that fictionalize
messages.messageBody:
Our library branch bought the whole PBS series
"Vietnam" It is surprisingly good. DH even watched all
of it. He refuses to view any movies that
fictionalize or dramatize that war. Perhaps a library
somewhere has this series?

Will Lars read for info? If so I can put together a
list of book suggestions.

Food (cook books, resteraunts), dance (religious and
secular), biology (flora and fauna...snakes etc) might
extend his interest. He might enjoy seeing a Veterans
Honoring Dance at a pow-wow.

Is there a veterans organization that meets somewhere?
If so, there are probably local vets who would allow
him to sit in on meetings, or perhaps they have
literature or someone has photographs (and personal
comments...take with a grain of salt) to share.
Actually take all of it with salt. History is created
in the telling.

MASH was Korea. Similar. But way different, too.

Sharon of the Swamp

--- Tia Leschke <leschke@...> wrote:
> Lars has been watching shows about war, seems mainly
> the Vietnam war, on
> the History Channel. (that and M.A.S.H. re-runs
> every night) I'm
> wondering if anyone can suggest movies or books that
> I could offer him that
> might extend this interest.
> Tia

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Vietnam War Movies, Books?
messages.msgSnippet: These are all good movies, some great, all intense: Apocolypse Now Full Metal Jacket The Deer Hunter Platoon Schindler s List Three Kings Empire of the Sun
messages.messageBody:
These are all good movies, some great, all intense:

Apocolypse Now
Full Metal Jacket
The Deer Hunter
Platoon
Schindler's List
Three Kings
Empire of the Sun
Saving Private Ryan
Bridge on the River Kwai
They Were Expendable
Run Silent, Run Deep
Das Boot
Retreat Hell
The Longest Day

Ha- and I would have said I don't really like war movies!

Paula

messages.subject: Vietnam War Movies, Books?
messages.msgSnippet: Lars has been watching shows about war, seems mainly the Vietnam war, on the History Channel.  (that and M.A.S.H. re-runs every night)  I m wondering if anyone
messages.messageBody:
Lars has been watching shows about war, seems mainly the Vietnam war, on
the History Channel. (that and M.A.S.H. re-runs every night) I'm
wondering if anyone can suggest movies or books that I could offer him that
might extend this interest.
Tia

No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
Eleanor Roosevelt

Tia Leschke
